newsitem.title: USA: OPTIONS - Dlr/yen vols climb after spot tumbles.
newsitem.headline: OPTIONS - Dlr/yen vols climb after spot tumbles.

text.p: Implied volatilities for dollar/yen options were strongly higher in U.S. trading Thursday after spot sank overnight on remarks by a senior Japanese Finance Ministry official about a stronger yen.
The dollar shed more than a full yen in Tokyo after Eisuke Sakakibara told a parliamentary panel it was possible the Japanese currency could strengthen to 103 yen.

Sakakibara also offered up a reminder that Japanese individuals should consider currency risk when investing overseas, which was taken as an indication of the government's resolve to support the yen, options traders said.

Strong bidding for currency calls, evident throughout the week, continued during the session, they said. Risk reversals, the put/call pricing differential, widened further to reflect the trend, pushing to 0.7/1.0 in favor of yen calls on the 25-delta options.
By afternoon, the dollar was bid at 123.81 yen, off its lows.
Implied volatility for one-month dollar/yen options climbed to 9.20/9.45 percent Thursday from 8.65/8.85 percent the previous session.
Dollar/mark volatility firmed but only slightly, rising to 8.50/8.75 percent from 8.45/8.65 percent previously.
An options trader for a U.S. bank said it would take a break below the psychologically important 1.70 level to roil dollar/mark volatility.
So far, the spot was holding above that level after skidding overnight along with dollar/yen.
Risk reversals for dollar/mark shifted to a mark call skew of 0.1/0.4 from a narrow mark put bias the day before.

Options traders said a large option in the 1.71 mark strike was set to expire Friday, which could have a gravitational pull on the spot price because the investor who is long the option has incentive to sell dollars above 1.71 to defend the position.
Traders also noted brisk activity in sterling/mark and dollar/sterling options during the session amid lingering fear of Labour devaluation that weighed on the U.K. currency.
